questions.text: CSF otorrhea can occur in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Temporal Bone fracture

 

CSF otorrhea is associated with Longitudinal Temporal Bone fracture.

 

Temporal bone fractures can be of types:

 

 

 

Battle’s sign is associated with temporal bone fracture.

 

 

Cribriform plate damage can lead to CSF rhinorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TM rupture due to trauma: While traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane may occur, it does not typically result in CSF otorrhea unless associated with a temporal bone fracture.

 

Option B. Stab injury in the eye: Unlikely to cause CSF otorrhea directly unless there is extensive cranial trauma involving the skull base.

 

Option C. Cribriform plate fracture: More commonly associated with CSF rhinorrhea (leakage of CSF from the nose) due to its location and relationship to the nasal cavity and sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF otorrhea is a serious condition often linked with fractures of the temporal bone. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent complications and promote effective healing. Monitoring for signs of infection or persistent leakage is essential, as these may necessitate more aggressive interventions.

questions.text: Indication for this incision: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open rhinoplasty

 

The image shows an incision along the columella and the nostrils, characteristic of an open rhinoplasty approach. In open rhinoplasty, this type of incision allows the surgeon to lift the skin over the nasal dorsum, providing direct visualization of the underlying bony and cartilaginous structures, including the alar cartilages and nasal bones. This approach is used for making precise adjustments to the shape of the external nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell luc: Caldwell-Luc surgery is a procedure primarily used for accessing the maxillary sinus. It involves making an incision in the gingivobuccal sulcus (inside the mouth) to enter the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall. This approach is not related to nasal dorsum access and does not involve incisions on the external nose.

 

 

Option B. Midfacial degloving: Midfacial degloving is a technique used for the removal of extensive nasopharyngeal tumors, such as juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas (JNA). It involves lifting the facial soft tissues, including the nasal mucosa, through incisions made intraorally. This method provides access to the nasal cavity and maxillary sinus but does not involve an incision like the one shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incision shown in the image is specific to open rhinoplasty, allowing direct access to the nasal structures for reshaping and reconstructive procedures.

questions.text: Most common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The image provided is an endoscopic view of the nasopharynx. The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, which is located posterior to the torus tubarius. The torus tubarius is an elevation formed by the cartilaginous portion of the Eustachian tube, and the fossa of Rosenmüller is the recess behind this elevation. Site number 2 in the image corresponds to the fossa of Rosenmüller, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: This represents the posterior pharyngeal wall, which is not the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option C. 3: This represents another area of the nasopharynx but is not the typical site for the origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option D. 4: This represents the opening of the Eustachian tube. While nasopharyngeal carcinoma can affect this area, it is not the most common primary site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius in the nasopharynx.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for balance and equilibrium? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Semicircular canal

 

The human balance system, or vestibular system, relies on structures within the inner ear to maintain balance and equilibrium. The primary structures involved in balance are the semicircular canals and the vestibule (which contains the utricle and saccule).

 

Semicircular canal: There are three semicircular canals (anterior, posterior, and lateral) in each ear, and they detect rotational movements of the head. The semicircular canals contain the crista ampullaris within the ampullae, which respond to angular movements, making them directly responsible for maintaining balance during such movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organ of Corti: This is the sensory organ of hearing located within the cochlea. It is responsible for detecting sound and converting it into nerve impulses but does not play a role in balance.

 

Option B. Cochlea: This spiral-shaped organ is part of the inner ear and is also involved in hearing. It converts sound vibrations into electrical signals that are sent to the brain but is not involved in balance.

 

Option C. Vestibule: This part of the inner ear contains the utricle and saccule, which are essential for detecting linear movements and head position relative to gravity. While the vestibule is crucial for balance, the specific detection of angular movements is primarily attributed to the semicircular canals.

 

While both the utricle and saccule, and the semicircular canals, are important for balance, the semicircular canals are particularly crucial for detecting angular motion, which is vital for maintaining equilibrium during movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The semicircular canals are critical for detecting angular movements and maintaining balance and equilibrium in conjunction with the vestibule, which detects linear movements and head position relative to gravity.

questions.text: A senior ENT specialist at the hospital is conducting the clinical examination depicted in the provided image. Which of the subsequent anatomical structures will not be visible to him? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arytenoids

 

While conducting a posterior rhinoscopy with the held post-nasal mirror, the specialist would not have a view of the arytenoids.

 

  • Arytenoids are seen on indirect laryngoscopy.
  • The posterior rhinoscopy mirror has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.
  • The structures seen in posterior rhinoscopy are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoids: These are clearly visible during posterior rhinoscopy, which is aimed at examining the nasopharynx, where the adenoids are located.

 

Option C. Torus tubarius: This structure, which surrounds the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube, is also visible during a posterior rhinoscopy.

 

Option D. Upper surface of soft palate: This area can be inspected during posterior rhinoscopy for signs of inflammation, lesions, or other abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The arytenoids are viewed using indirect laryngoscopy, not posterior rhinoscopy, due to their location in the larynx. Posterior rhinoscopy provides visualization of the nasopharyngeal region, aiding in the assessment of structures like adenoids, torus tubarius, and the upper surface of the soft palate, important for diagnosing various nasopharyngeal conditions.

 

Additional Information

 

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication for low tracheostomy? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Emergency airway obstruction

 

Explanation:

 

Emergency airway obstruction requires rapid access to the airway, and a low tracheostomy would be time-consuming and technically more challenging due to:

  • Deeper location
  • More complex anatomy including thyroid isthmus
  • Greater risk of bleeding
  • Need for proper positioning and lighting

 

In emergencies, cricothyroidotomy is preferred as it's:

  • Quicker to perform
  • More superficial
  • Has fewer vital structures
  • Can be converted to formal tracheostomy later

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord palsy - Low tracheostomy is appropriate as it preserves upper airway anatomy and allows for potential future procedures

 

Option B. Tracheomalacia - Low tracheostomy is indicated as it provides access below the affected segment and avoids compromising already weakened tracheal structure

 

Option D. Subglottic stenosis - Low tracheostomy is preferred as it avoids the stenosed segment and provides stable airway below the pathology

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the anatomical and temporal considerations in airway management is crucial. While low tracheostomy is preferred for most elective cases, emergency situations may require faster alternatives like cricothyroidotomy for immediate airway access.

questions.text: A patient complained of ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and visual disturbances. What is the diagnosis: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Petrositis

 

Petrositis, specifically Gradenigo's syndrome, is characterized by a triad of symptoms: deep-seated retro-orbital pain, ear discharge, and sixth nerve palsy causing diplopia (double vision). This condition is a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) and involves inflammation of the petrous part of the temporal bone, which can impinge on the adjacent cranial nerves.

 

  1. Ear discharge is due to the ongoing infection chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) in the middle ear extending into the petrous apex.
  2. Retro-orbital pain occurs due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve) as the petrous apex is adjacent to Meckel's cave, where the trigeminal ganglion is located.
  3. Visual disturbances (diplopia) are due to sixth cranial nerve palsy. The abducens nerve passes through Dorello's canal beneath the petrous apex and can be affected by the inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral sinus thrombosis: This condition can occur as a complication of middle ear infections but does not typically present with visual disturbances. The symptoms usually include severe headache, fever, and neck stiffness.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: This inner ear condition usually presents with vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus, rather than visual disturbances or retro-orbital pain.

 

Option D. Mastoiditis: An infection of the mastoid bone that often presents with pain and tenderness over the mastoid, fever, ear discharge and conductive hearing loss. It does not typically cause retro-orbital pain or visual disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gradenigo's syndrome (Petrositis) presents with the triad of ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and sixth nerve palsy causing visual disturbances. This is due to the spread of chronic ear infection to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, affecting adjacent cranial nerves.

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the ENT OPD with complaints of abnormal noise during breathing, the severity of which increases during crying. On examination, inspiratory stridors are heard and on laryngoscopy, the following finding is seen. The diagnosis would be? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laryngomalacia

 

Explanation: 

 

The baby presents with abnormal noise during breathing that worsens with crying, and inspiratory stridor, indicating an upper airway issue. The laryngoscopy image shows an omega-shaped epiglottis, which is characteristic of laryngomalacia. Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in infants and results from the collapse of the supraglottic structures during inspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital laryngeal web: A congenital laryngeal web would present with a hoarse cry and respiratory distress due to the fusion of the vocal cords. The airway would be significantly compromised, as shown below.

 

 

Option C. Congenital subglottic stenosis: Subglottic stenosis would show a narrowed subglottic area below the vocal cords, which is not consistent with the omega-shaped epiglottis seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Congenital bilateral choanal atresia: Choanal atresia involves the blockage of the nasal passages and presents with difficulty breathing, particularly while feeding, but does not typically present with the findings of an omega-shaped epiglottis or inspiratory stridor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying and is identified by the presence of an omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with severe posterior epistaxis. After failed bilateral anterior and posterior nasal packing, angiography reveals active bleeding from ethmoidal region. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligation of anterior ethmoidal artery

 

Explanation: 

 

The case suggests ethmoidal artery bleeding because:

  • Angiography identifies ethmoidal region as bleeding source
  • Failed nasal packing indicates high location of bleeding
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery is accessible through external ethmoidectomy approach
  • Branch of ophthalmic artery making it inappropriate for external carotid approaches

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. External carotid artery: Too non-specific and won't address ethmoidal bleeding from ophthalmic system 

 

Option B. Internal carotid artery: Never ligated for epistaxis due to severe neurological risks 

 

Option D. Maxillary artery: Would not address bleeding from ethmoidal arteries which are from internal carotid system

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anatomical source of bleeding dictates surgical approach: 
    • Posterior bleeding (sphenopalatine) → endoscopic SPA ligation
    • Superior/ethmoidal bleeding → external approach for ethmoidal arteries
    • Multiple sites → consider embolization
  • Important to identify arterial system involved: 
    • External carotid system → maxillary/sphenopalatine
    • Internal carotid system → ethmoidal arteries
  • Failed packing should prompt imaging to identify bleeding source
  • Surgical approach should target specific vessel rather than main arterial trunks

questions.text: A boy with ASOM underwent treatment for the same. Now he presents with subsidence of pain but persistence of deafness. On examination of TM, the following findings are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secretory otitis media

 

Explanation:

 

The boy has undergone treatment for Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) and now presents with subsidence of pain but persistence of deafness. The otoscopic examination reveals air-fluid levels behind an intact tympanic membrane, indicative of fluid in the middle ear. This condition is known as secretory otitis media (also called otitis media with effusion), where the middle ear is filled with sterile fluid, leading to conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ototoxicity: Ototoxicity refers to damage to the inner ear structures, particularly the hair cells, due to exposure to certain ototoxic drugs (e.g., aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, cisplatin). This results in sensorineural hearing loss and is not characterized by air-fluid levels in the middle ear.

 

Option C. Adhesive otitis media: Adhesive otitis media is characterized by the retraction of the tympanic membrane, which adheres to the medial wall of the middle ear. This condition results from chronic eustachian tube dysfunction and does not typically present with air-fluid levels as seen in secretory otitis media.

 

 

Option D. Tympanosclerosis: Tympanosclerosis involves the formation of calcium plaques within the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane or middle ear due to recurrent infections. This leads to stiffening of the tympanic membrane and conductive hearing loss. The otoscopic findings show calcific deposits, not fluid levels.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory otitis media is characterized by the presence of sterile fluid in the middle ear, resulting in conductive hearing loss, and is often seen following the treatment of ASOM.

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane
  4. Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells
  5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct 

This choice correctly identifies that inner hair cells transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in multiple rows and aid in the functionality related to cochlear amplification, and that there is a numerical dominance of outer hair cells compared to inner hair cells. 

The correct statements regarding the roles and arrangements of inner and outer hair cells within the cochlea, based on the options given, are as follows:

1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses: This statement is correct. Inner hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory signals to the brain. They are fewer in number compared to outer hair cells and are arranged in a single row along the length of the cochlea.

2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells: This is correct. Outer hair cells are indeed arranged in 3-4 rows. They play a crucial role in amplifying and fine-tuning the vibrations within the cochlea through their motility, which affects how the inner hair cells respond to sound. 

5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1: This statement is  correct. There are significantly more outer hair cells than inner hair cells, typically at a ratio close to 3:1, reflecting their arrangement in multiple rows compared to the single row of inner hair cells.

Other Options:

3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the tectorial membrane: This statement is incorrect. Outer hair cells do contribute to the movement of the tectorial membrane through their motility and changes in length, but it's more accurate to say they influence the fluid mechanics around the inner hair cells, affecting how the tectorial membrane interacts with them.

4. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate function of outer hair cells: This statement is incorrect. Inner hair cells do not modulate the function of outer hair cells; rather, they function primarily as sensory transducers sending information to the brain.

Educational Objective: 

The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

choices.text: Antibiotics and Peroral Incision and Drainage

questions.text: A child presented to your clinic with complaints of severe respiratory distress, chin swelling, and difficulty in opening mouth. He gives a history of dental infection a week ago. Examination findings given below. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tracheostomy

 

Explanation:

 

The child presents with severe respiratory distress and swelling suggestive of Ludwig's angina, a severe cellulitis of the submandibular space. This condition can rapidly compromise the airway by pushing the anterior respiratory wall posteriorly, leading to obstruction. Given the severity of the respiratory distress, securing the airway is the priority, and tracheostomy is the recommended emergency procedure to ensure an adequate airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early intubation: While securing the airway is critical, intubation can be challenging and potentially hazardous in the presence of significant submandibular swelling.

 

Option B. External Incision and Drainage: This may be necessary after securing the airway but is not the immediate step in severe respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Antibiotics and Peroral Incision and Drainage: Antibiotics are essential, but in the acute setting of airway compromise, they do not provide immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe respiratory distress due to Ludwig's angina, a tracheostomy is the immediate step to secure the airway and prevent obstruction.

questions.text: What is this maneuver primarily used for? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior epistaxis control

 

Explanation:


In anterior epistaxis, pinching the nose is essential and mouth breathing isn't specifically required. The focus is on applying direct pressure to the bleeding site.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Posterior epistaxis control: Posterior epistaxis requires more aggressive management including posterior packing and often needs hospital admission. Simple positioning alone is insufficient.


Option C. While this posture (sitting and leaning forward with mouth breathing) appears similar to Trotter's method, this positioning is critical for managing hemoptysis:

 

  • The forward-leaning position helps prevent aspiration of blood into the airways by allowing gravity to assist in draining blood forward through the mouth
  • Mouth breathing is essential as it allows for better expectoration of blood while maintaining clear airways
  • Pinching the nose, unlike in epistaxis management, serves no purpose in hemoptysis and would actually be counterproductive

 

Option D. Management of oral bleeding: For oral bleeding, the positioning would be similar but specific modifications would be needed based on the source of bleeding (tongue, gums, etc.).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding proper positioning for hemoptysis management is crucial for preventing complications like aspiration pneumonia. The forward-leaning posture with mouth breathing optimizes airway protection and blood drainage, while allowing for easier expectoration.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with chronic ear discharge presents with severe vertigo, ataxia, headache, nausea, and tendency to fall towards the right side. On examination, there is foul-smelling discharge from right ear with cholesteatoma. Which complication should be suspected? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebellar abscess

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical scenario suggests cerebellar abscess because:

 

  • Presence of vertigo and ataxia indicates cerebellar involvement
  • Directional fall suggests localized cerebellar pathology
  • Association with cholesteatoma is significant risk factor
  • Combination of otologic and neurological symptoms is characteristic

 

Other Option: 

 

Option A Temporal lobe abscess: Presents with aphasia, seizures, or behavioral changes rather than vertigo 

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: Though causes vertigo, wouldn't explain the headache and neurological symptoms

 

Option D. Meningitis: Would present with neck rigidity and more diffuse symptoms

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cerebellar abscess characteristics: 
    • Presents with vertigo, ataxia, and directional falling
    • Often associated with chronic ear disease/cholesteatoma
    • Requires urgent intervention due to posterior fossa location
    • Can cause rapid deterioration due to brainstem compression
  • Key differences from temporal abscess: 
    • Cerebellar signs predominate
    • More likely to cause hydrocephalus
    • Higher risk of sudden deterioration
    • Different surgical approach needed

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The presentation of a child with a type B tympanometry curve indicates the likelihood of serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy as the underlying cause.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: While this can relieve middle ear effusion, it does not address the underlying adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Similar to grommet insertion alone, this option does not address the root cause of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: This procedure involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure or drain fluid but does not address the cause or provide a lasting solution like adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is the most appropriate management for a child presenting with serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy, addressing both the immediate symptoms and underlying cause.

questions.text: All of the following are initial management options of CSF rhinorrhea except: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids followed by FESS

 

Steroids followed by FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): This option is incorrect because steroids and FESS are primarily used for treating chronic rhinosinusitis and nasal polyposis. FESS is not an initial management option for CSF rhinorrhea; it is not related to repairing the skull base defect causing the CSF leak.

 

CSF rhinorrhea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid through the nose, often due to a defect in the skull base. Initial management focuses on conservative measures to allow spontaneous healing and to prevent complications such as meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bed rest: Advising the patient to take bed rest and avoid activities that increase intracranial pressure is a standard initial approach. This helps reduce the flow of CSF and may allow the defect to heal on its own.

 

Option C. HRCT (High-Resolution CT): HRCT is useful for diagnosing the exact site and cause of the CSF leak. It helps in planning further treatment if conservative measures fail.

 

Option D. Antibiotics and Acetazolamide: Antibiotics are given to prevent infections such as meningitis. Acetazolamide, a diuretic, reduces CSF production and intracranial pressure, which can help reduce the leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of CSF rhinorrhea includes conservative measures such as bed rest, use of acetazolamide, and antibiotics to prevent infection. Diagnostic imaging like HRCT can help identify the defect. Steroids followed by FESS is not appropriate for the initial management of CSF rhinorrhea as it is unrelated to addressing the CSF leak.

questions.text: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Outer hair cells

 

  • Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) causes damage to outer hair cells.
  • NIHL Hearing loss, in this case, is due to chronic exposure.
  • It can be of two types
     
    1. Temporary threshold shift (TTS). The hearing is impaired immediately after exposure to noise but recovers after an interval of a few minutes to a few hours even up to 2 weeks
    2. Permanent threshold shift (PTS). The hearing impairment is permanent and does not recover at all.

 

The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction. This is referred to as acoustic dip or Boiler's notch.

 

 

The damage caused by noise trauma depends on several factors:

 

  1. Frequency of noise. A frequency of 2000–3000 Hz causes more damage than lower or higher frequencies.
  2. Intensity and duration of noise. As the intensity increases, permissible time for exposure is reduced.
  3. Continuous noise is more harmful.
  4. Susceptibility of the individual. Degree of TTS and PTS varies in different individuals.
  5. Pre-existing ear disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crista ampullaris: This structure is located within the semicircular canals of the inner ear and is primarily involved in sensing rotational movements of the head, not in hearing. Thus, it is not typically affected by noise-induced hearing loss.

 

Option B. Macula: Found in the utricle and saccule of the vestibular system, the macula detects linear accelerations and head tilts but is not directly involved in the auditory response to sound waves.

 

Option C. Cupola: The cupola is a gelatin-like structure in the vestibular system's semicircular canals that responds to changes in head position. Like the crista ampullaris, it is unrelated to the hearing process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noise-induced hearing loss specifically damages the outer hair cells in the cochlea, leading to hearing impairment.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 36, 37

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe abscess

 

The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

 

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication of CSOM.

 

Localizing symptoms of temporal lobe abscess -

 

  1. Nominal aphasia. If abscess involves dominant hemisphere, i.e. left hemisphere in right-handed persons, patient fails to tell the names of common objects such as key, pen, etc. but can demonstrate their use.
  2. Homonymous hemianopia. This is due to pressure on the optic radiations. Visual field, opposite to the side of the lesion, is lost. It can be elicited by confrontation test, by standing in front of the patient and comparing his visual field with that of the examiner, or by perimeter. The defect is usually in the upper, but sometimes in the lower quadrants.
  3. Contralateral motor paralysis. In the usual upward spread of abscess, the face is involved first followed by the arm and leg. Inward spread, towards the internal capsule, involves the leg first followed by the arm and the face.
  4. Epileptic fits. Involvement of uncinate gyrus causes hallucinations of taste, and smell and involuntary smacking movements of lips and tongue. Generalized fits may occur.

 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.

 

Management:

 

  1. IV antibiotics (usually third generation cephalosporin +/- metronidazole) are started. Aminoglycosides are added if pseudomonas infection is suspected. Culture and sensitivity of ear swabs can guide antibiotic therapy.
  2.  Raised intracranial tension can be lowered by dexamethasone, 4 mg i.v. 6 hourly or mannitol 20% in doses of 0.5 g/kg body weight
  3. Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebellar abscess: Would likely present with different symptoms, including severe dizziness, balance problems, and coordination difficulties.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Usually presents with more diffuse cerebral symptoms and different radiological features.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Characterized by severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia, with different findings on lumbar puncture and imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of chronic ear infections that requires prompt recognition and aggressive treatment to prevent further neurological damage and potential life-threatening complications.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 90, 91

questions.text: The following image shows which X-ray view?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Towne’s view

 

Based on the image provided, where the X-ray beam is directed from above the skull at an angle and the detector is positioned below the skull, the indicated X-ray view is consistent with the Towne’s view.

 

Towne’s view is an X-ray where the beam is angled at approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and directed downward toward the patient's head, which is positioned with the chin lifted. This view is particularly useful for assessing the occipital bone, posterior fossa, and foramen magnum, as well as the mastoid and middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view is an X-ray taken with the patient's head tilted backward so that the X-ray beam is directed perpendicularly to the orbitomeatal line. It's often used to visualize the maxillary sinuses, the orbits, and the nasal cavity.

 

Option B. Caldwell view is performed with the patient’s head positioned such that the X-ray beam is angled at 15-20 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and the central ray is directed towards the nose. This view is used to visualize the frontal sinuses, orbits, and ethmoid sinuses.

 

Option D. Schuller’s view is an X-ray that provides a lateral view of the skull, specifically to evaluate the mastoid air cells and the structure of the temporal bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Towne’s view X-ray is used to visualize the occipital bone, posterior fossa, foramen magnum, and mastoid process by positioning the patient with the head tilted upward and the X-ray beam angled approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents in ENT OPD with complaints of hearing trouble from the left side of the ear for the last 2 months. The doctor performs pure tone audiometry shown below. Interpret the audiogram? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left sided conductive deafness

 

Explanation:

 

The pure tone audiometry (PTA) shows results for the left ear, indicated by the blue color. The audiogram demonstrates a significant air-bone gap, which is characteristic of conductive hearing loss. In conductive hearing loss, the air conduction thresholds are worse (higher dB levels) than the bone conduction thresholds, but the bone conduction remains within normal limits. This wide air-bone gap confirms the diagnosis of left-sided conductive deafness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left side sensorineural deafness: Sensorineural hearing loss would present with both air and bone conduction thresholds being equally impaired, without a significant air-bone gap. This is not the case here.

 

Option C. Right sided conductive deafness: The audiogram is for the left ear (indicated by blue color), not the right ear. Hence, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Right sided sensorineural deafness: Similarly, this option is incorrect as the audiogram provided is for the left ear, and it shows conductive, not sensorineural, hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conductive hearing loss is indicated by a significant air-bone gap on pure tone audiometry, with air conduction thresholds being worse than bone conduction thresholds, as seen in this left-sided case

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly damaged after parotid surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

 

The Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII) is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid gland surgery due to its anatomical course through the gland. Damage to this nerve can result in facial paralysis or weakness, affecting expressions and other functions like eyelid closure and stapedius muscle reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Trigeminal nerve (Cranial Nerve V) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing. It is less commonly damaged during parotid surgery because of its location and the type of sensory and motor innervation it provides.

 

Option C. The Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX) is involved in taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue and swallowing. It is not typically at risk during parotid surgery as it does not traverse the parotid gland like the facial nerve.

 

Option D. The Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI) innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles and is not usually at risk during parotid surgery because it does not run through the parotid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Facial nerve is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid surgery due to its anatomical path through the parotid gland, making it vulnerable to injury during surgical procedures involving this gland

questions.text: Anterior ethmoidal sinus drains into: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle meatus

 

The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary sinus and frontal sinus, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. The middle meatus is a crucial drainage pathway for these sinuses, allowing mucus to flow from the sinuses into the nasal cavity. This drainage is essential for maintaining sinus health and preventing infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, not the ethmoidal sinuses.

 

Option C. Superior meatus: The superior meatus is the drainage site for the posterior ethmoidal sinus.

 

Option D. Nasal cavity: This is a general term and does not specify the precise drainage pathway for the anterior ethmoidal sinus, which specifically drains into the middle meatus.

 

Additionally, the sphenoid sinuses drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary and frontal sinuses, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with a painful swelling over the forehead following trauma. CT scan shows: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subperiosteal hematoma of frontal bone

 

Explanation:

 

In this case, the presentation is different from Pott's puffy tumor because:

  • The age of presentation is 12 years, when frontal sinus is just developing
  • The etiology is traumatic rather than infectious
  • There is acute onset following trauma without infectious symptoms
  • The underlying pathology is hemorrhagic rather than infectious

 

Subperiosteal hematoma of the frontal bone:

  • Results from trauma causing separation of periosteum from bone
  • Presents as a soft, fluctuant swelling confined to the frontal bone
  • No signs of infection like fever or local warmth initially
  • May need surgical evacuation if large or symptomatic

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone: Pott's puffy tumor is primarily infectious in origin, showing signs of infection and typically occurs as a complication of sinusitis

 

Option C. Mucocele of frontal bone: Mucocele development is gradual and related to sinus outflow obstruction, not acute trauma

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis of frontal bone: Osteomyelitis without preceding infection would be unlikely in acute trauma; it may develop as a late complication if the hematoma becomes infected

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the difference between infectious and traumatic causes of frontal bone swelling is crucial for appropriate management. While both may present with similar external appearance, the etiology, patient demographics, and management differ significantly.

questions.text: A person presents with a tongue ulcer persisting for 3 months. Upon examination, a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm is observed, accompanied by an 8 mm area of hardened tissue. No lymph node enlargement is detected. According to the 8th AJCC guidelines, what stage does this lesion correspond to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage II

 

In the given case can be classified as T2N0M0 as per AJCC 2002 as the size of the lesion is between 2-4 cm (T2) with no nodal (N0) or distant metastasis (M0) and that will come under Stage II disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I: This stage would be applicable for T1 tumors, which are 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, and does not fit the description of the lesion presented.

 

Option C. Stage III: This stage would involve either T3 tumors, which are greater than 4 cm, or any T1-T3 tumors with N1 lymph node involvement, neither of which applies to this case.

 

Option D. Stage IV: This stage is reserved for more advanced disease involving T4 tumors, any tumor with N2 or N3 lymph node involvement, or distant metastasis (M1), which are not applicable in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 256

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne’s negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-45 dB

 

The given clinical scenario of hearing loss with a negative Rinne at 256 Hz and 512 Hz and positive Rinne at 1024 Hz indicates air conduction and bone conduction gap of 30-45 dB.

 

  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz tuning fork (TF) but positive for 512Hz tuning fork → approximate hearing loss will be 20-30dB.
  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz & 512Hz TF but positive for 1024Hz TF → approximate hearing loss will be 30–45dB
  • Rinne’s negative for all 256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz → approximate hearing loss will be 45-60dB.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the photograph:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasal Hopkin's endoscope

 

Explanation: 

 

The instrument shown in the photograph is a Nasal Hopkin's endoscope. This endoscope is commonly used in ENT endoscopic procedures to provide a clear and magnified view of the nasal and sinus passages. It consists of a rigid rod lens system that allows visualization of the internal structures during diagnostic and surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frazier's straight suction tube: Frazier's straight suction tube is a different instrument used for suction during surgeries, particularly in nasal surgeries.

 

 

Option C. Atomizer: An atomizer is a device used to convert liquid medication into a fine mist for nasal application.

 

 

Option D. Tilley antral trochar and canula: The Tilley antral trochar and canula are used for procedures such as antral lavage or drainage of the maxillary sinus, particularly in Caldwell-Luc surgeries.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nasal Hopkin's endoscope is a critical tool in ENT endoscopic procedures, providing detailed visualization of nasal and sinus structures for both diagnostic and surgical purposes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with progressive hoarseness for 6 months. She is a heavy smoker with 30 pack-years of smoking history. On laryngoscopic examination, the following lesion is noted: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reinke's edema

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows diffuse edematous swelling of the vocal cords characteristic of Reinke's edema.

 

Reinke's edema (Polypoid corditis)

 

  • Most common in middle-aged female smokers
  • Characterized by bilateral diffuse swelling of the vocal cords due to accumulation of fluid in the superficial lamina propria (Reinke's space)
  • Strong association with smoking, voice abuse, and GERD
  • Presents with progressive hoarseness and deep voice
  • On examination, shows translucent, bag-like swelling of vocal cords that moves with respiration
  • Treatment involves smoking cessation and microsurgical removal of excess tissue
  • Good prognosis if smoking is discontinued

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignancy: Would show more irregular, ulcerative or exophytic growth patterns with possible cord fixation

 

Option C. Tracheomalacia: Involves weakening of tracheal cartilage, not relevant to vocal cord lesions

 

Option D. Laryngeal papilloma: Shows multiple warty, exophytic growths; more common in children; HPV-related

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Reinke's edema is a smoking-related condition causing bilateral vocal cord swelling due to fluid accumulation in Reinke's space. Recognition of its characteristic appearance and strong association with smoking is crucial for proper management.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year. Transnasal endoscopic results are shown below. A contrast-enhanced CT revealed a mass filling posterior choana to the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

The above clinical scenario with recurrent spontaneous bleeding with unilateral nasal obstruction and contrast-enhanced CT showing a growth protruding into the nasopharynx, along with the Transnasal endoscopic image, is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

 

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor. It is predominantly seen in adolescent males and is thought to be testosterone-dependent. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity near the sphenopalatine foramen. 

 

Clinical features –

 

  • Epistaxis
  • Progressive nasal obstruction
  • Denasal speech
  • CHL
  • Broadening of nasal bridge
  • Proptosis leading to frog-face deformity
  • Involvement of cranial nerves – II, III, IV and VI

 

IOC is CECT – anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Millar sign)

 

Biopsy is avoided.

 

Treatment of choice – surgical approach

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antrochoanal Polyp: Typically arises from the maxillary sinus and extends into the choana, generally not as aggressive or vascular.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma: A chronic granulomatous condition caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the nasal passages and respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Concha Bullosa: An aerated turbinate that usually does not present with bleeding or significant obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Prompt and accurate diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is critical due to its potential for significant bleeding and local invasiveness. Treatment typically involves surgical removal, with preoperative planning crucial to manage the vascular nature of the tumor effectively.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

The given clinical scene and image shows a post-op tracheal stump created for breathing in patients of total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma.

 

In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, are removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration.

 

Complications after total laryngectomy:

 

  • Permanent tracheostomy: upper end of trachea is directly sutured to skin for the patient to breathe.
  • Speech difficulties: To help patient speak after removal of larynx, there are various techniques.

 

1. Oesophageal speech:  patient is taught to swallow air and release which vibrates pharyngo-oesophageal segment and produces a very low sound.

 

2. Tracheo-oesophageal speech: most effective, artificial prostheses like Blom-singer valve / Provox / Groningen are inserted.

 

3. Electrolarynx: electrical device held on the skin of the neck vibrates and produce voice.

 

  • Loss of smell and decreased taste sensation
  • Swallowing difficulty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy: Is performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening.

 

Option B. Percutaneous tracheostomy: Is a minimally invasive surgical procedure done in ICU patients to create an opening in the trachea for breathing support. The image below shows the procedure of percutaneous tracheostomy.

 

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy: Involves creating a larger incision in the neck to access the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total laryngectomy is a radical yet life-saving procedure for patients with extensive laryngeal cancer, resulting in significant anatomical and functional changes.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in higher frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval window

 

The affected structure in high-frequency hearing loss is the basal turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies near it is the oval window.

 

Movements of the stapes footplate, transmitted to the cochlear fluids, move the basilar membrane and set up shearing force between the tectorial membrane and the hair cells. The distortion of hair cells gives rise to cochlear microphonics, which trigger the nerve impulse. A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment (travelling wave theory of von Bekesy). Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: The central core of the cochlea around which the cochlear duct spirals. While important, it does not lie near the basal turn directly affected in high-frequency hearing loss.

 

Option B. Stria Vascularis: Located on the outer wall of the cochlear duct and is responsible for producing the endolymph. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph but is not located near the oval window.

 

Option D. Helicotrema: The apex of the cochlea where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet, it is relevant for the transmission of lower frequency sounds, not high frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of high-frequency hearing loss, the basal turn of the cochlea near the oval window is typically involved. Understanding the anatomical proximity of the oval window to the basal turn helps in pinpointing the site of lesion and aids in specific diagnostic and therapeutic approaches aimed at the high-frequency hearing spectrum.

questions.text: A patient presented in the ENT OPD with nasal obstruction. On examination, a mulberry-shaped hypertrophied inferior turbinate was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypertrophic Rhinitis

 

Given clinical scenario suggests diagnosis of Hypertrophic rhinitis.

 

Hypertrophic Rhinitis is characterized by chronic inflammation leading to the thickening of the mucosal lining and the underlying connective tissue of the nasal turbinates, particularly the inferior turbinates. This condition can manifest as a "mulberry" appearance due to the irregular, hypertrophic mucosal surface, which is a hallmark sign of turbinate hypertrophy.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Nasal Obstruction: The primary symptom due to enlarged turbinates.
  • Mulberry Appearance of Turbinate: Visualized during nasal examination, indicating significant mucosal hypertrophy.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • Chronic Inflammation: Often triggered by prolonged episodes of rhinitis, allergens, or irritants, leading to mucosal edema and fibrosis.
  • Submucosal Fibrosis: Contributes to the persistent swelling and hypertrophy of the turbinates.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Medical Management: Includes nasal corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and antihistamines if allergies are a contributing factor.
  • Surgical Intervention: Turbinectomy or turbinate reduction surgery may be required for severe cases where medical treatment fails to relieve symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common Cold: Typically presents with temporary nasal congestion and discharge, resolving without long-term hypertrophy.

 

Option B. Nasal Polyp: Polyps are soft, painless, noncancerous growths on the lining of nasal passages or sinuses, hanging down like teardrops or grapes. They are not described as mulberry-shaped.

 

Option D. Atrophic Rhinitis: Characterized by the thinning and drying of the nasal mucosa, leading to crust formation and a foul odor, not hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophic Rhinitis involves chronic inflammation leading to noticeable enlargement and characteristic textural changes in the nasal turbinates, often requiring a combination of medical and surgical treatments to manage symptoms effectively and improve nasal airflow.

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Start IV antibiotics, apply local pressure with adrenaline-soaked gauze, and observe
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.text: A patient who underwent tonsillectomy 7 days ago presents to emergency with bleeding from the oral cavity. The patient has fever and examination shows sloughing at tonsillar fossa with active oozing. What will be your immediate management? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start IV antibiotics, apply local pressure with adrenaline-soaked gauze, and observe

 

Explanation: 

 

This case presents secondary hemorrhage because:

  • Occurs 7 days post-operation (typical 5-10 day window)
  • Associated with fever suggesting infection
  • Presence of sloughing indicates local sepsis
  • Initial management is conservative with antibiotics and local measures

 

Other Option: 

 

Option A. Immediate OT exploration: Not first-line for secondary hemorrhage unless conservative measures fail 

 

Option C. Anticoagulants: Contraindicated in active bleeding 

 

Option D. Blood transfusion alone: Doesn't address underlying cause of infection

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary hemorrhage characteristics: 
    • Occurs 5-10 days post-surgery
    • Associated with infection/sepsis
    • Preceded by throat pain/fever
    • Local sloughing visible
  • Management differs from reactionary hemorrhage: 
    • Start with conservative measures
    • IV antibiotics are crucial
    • Local hemostatic measures often sufficient
    • Surgical intervention only if conservative management fails
  • Prevention includes proper post-operative care and antibiotic compliance

choices.text: It may lead to pugilistic ear
It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space
All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented at the hospital with a reported history of ear trauma. Upon examination, there was observed swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resolves spontaneously

 

The condition depicted in the image is perichondrial hematoma, commonly resulting from blunt trauma to the ear. This condition does not resolve spontaneously and requires medical intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the permanent deformity known as cauliflower ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It may lead to pugilistic ear: This is true. If untreated, the hematoma can lead to fibrosis and calcification, causing a deformity known as cauliflower ear or pugilistic ear.

 

Option B. It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: True. The swelling and discoloration are due to blood accumulating in the perichondrial space, which separates the ear cartilage from the overlying skin.

 

Option D. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics: This is considered a good practice to prevent infection, especially since the ear's vascular supply is compromised, increasing the risk of perichondritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondrial hematoma does not resolve on its own and requires prompt medical treatment to prevent complications like infection and the formation of cauliflower ear. Management typically involves aspiration of the hematoma, application of a pressure dressing to maintain ear contour, and administration of prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with noisy breathing that worsens during physical activity. The noise is most pronounced during: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subglottic lesions

 

Explanation:

 

The question has been modified to focus on subglottic lesions which typically cause biphasic stridor, being most prominent during physical activity.

  • Characteristics of stridor based on anatomical location: 
    • Subglottic lesions - Biphasic stridor (both inspiratory and expiratory) 
      • Common causes: Subglottic stenosis, subglottic hemangioma
      • Worsens with activity due to increased airflow requirements
      • Often associated with history of prolonged intubation
      • May present with barking cough and hoarseness

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraglottic lesions: Cause predominantly inspiratory stridor due to tissue collapse during inspiration

 

Option C. Tracheal lesions: Usually cause expiratory stridor or biphasic stridor depending on location and severity

 

Option D. Bronchial lesions: Primarily cause expiratory wheezing/stridor due to dynamic airway compression during expiration

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the relationship between anatomical location of airway lesions and the timing of stridor is crucial for accurate diagnosis. Subglottic lesions typically cause biphasic stridor that worsens with activity, reflecting the fixed nature of the narrowing affecting both phases of respiration

questions.text: Which of the following is not ligated for the control of epistaxis?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal carotid artery

 

Internal carotid artery is not ligated in epistaxis control due to high percentage of cerebral complications and high mortality.

 

Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control:

 

  • Trans nasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine artery - TESPAL
  • If not controlled, maxillary artery ligation
  • If still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation
  • In case, the bleeding site is superior to the level of middle turbinate, then anterior and posterior ethmoidal vessels should be ligated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal artery: This artery may be ligated if the bleeding site is superior to the level of the middle turbinate, as it is one of the contributing vessels to the nasal cavity that might be involved in epistaxis.

 

Option C. Maxillary artery: Ligation of the maxillary artery is considered if epistaxis is not controlled by less invasive methods such as the ligation of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option D. External carotid artery: As a last resort, if bleeding persists despite ligation of more specific branches, ligation of the external carotid artery may be performed to control severe epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of severe epistaxis, it is critical to understand the hierarchy of arterial ligation, starting with the least risky options. The internal carotid artery should never be ligated due to its vital role in cerebral blood supply, highlighting the importance of targeted vascular control in surgical interventions to minimize complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a feature of malignant otitis externa? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple perforations

 

Explanation: 

 

Multiple perforations are NOT a feature of malignant otitis externa because:

  • MOE affects external ear canal without tympanic membrane involvement
  • Disease process starts in external canal and spreads to deeper tissues
  • Tympanic membrane typically remains intact unless very advanced
  • Multiple perforations are characteristic of tubercular otitis media instead

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Severe otalgia: Intense, deep-seated pain is characteristic 

 

Option C. Granulations in external canal: Classic finding at bone-cartilage junction 

 

Option D. Cranial nerve palsies: Particularly facial nerve, due to deep tissue invasion

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Malignant otitis externa characteristics: 
    • Severe, persistent otalgia
    • Granulation tissue at bone-cartilage junction
    • Predominantly affects diabetic/immunocompromised patients
    • Can lead to skull base osteomyelitis
  • Key diagnostic features: 
    • External canal findings without TM perforation
    • Progressive cranial nerve involvement
    • Positive Tc-99 scan
    • Pseudomonas is most common organism
  • Early recognition crucial for preventing complications

choices.text: Identify the source of bleeding
Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding in the external auditory canal following trauma. The next step in management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

 

Given the situation of trauma and the presence of blood in the external auditory canal, the most appropriate next step is to keep the ear dry to avoid any additional complications and to provide oral medications for pain, possible infection, and to reduce inflammation.

 

Keeping the ear dry and giving oral medications is a standard approach for managing a bloody discharge from the ear following trauma. This usually includes avoiding water in the ear to prevent infection and prescribing oral antibiotics if there is a suspicion of bacterial infection. Pain relief medication may also be provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirating the clot is generally not the first step in management unless there's a need for immediate assessment of the underlying structures, and if there's concern for ongoing bleeding that may be occluding the canal and impeding examination.

 

Option B. Identifying the source of bleeding is important, especially if the bleeding is significant or ongoing. However, this would typically follow initial conservative management unless the bleeding is profuse.

 

Option D. Syringing (ear irrigation) is contraindicated in the presence of a bloody discharge following trauma, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and increase the risk of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After trauma to the external auditory canal with bloody discharge, it is important to keep the ear dry and initiate treatment with oral medications, such as analgesics and possibly antibiotics, to manage pain, prevent infection, and reduce inflammation.

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The structure given in the image is the incus.

 

The malleus has head, neck, handle (manubrium), a lateral and an anterior process. Head and neck of malleus lie in the attic. Manubrium is embedded in the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane. The lateral process forms a knob-like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which hangs vertically and attaches to the head of stapes.

 

The stapes has a head, neck, anterior and posterior crura, and a footplate. The footplate is held in the oval window by annular ligament.


Other Options:

 

Option A. The malleus is the largest ossicle and is shaped like a mallet. The parts of the malleus are the head, neck, handle (manubrium), and anterior and lateral processes. The head and neck lie in the attic.

 

The tympanic membrane is connected to the handle of the malleus.

 

Option C. The stapes has a head, neck, footplate, and anterior and posterior crura. The annular ligament holds the footplate of stapes in the oval window.

 

 

The joints between the ear ossicles are synovial joints. A saddle-shaped joint is present between the incus and malleus. Incus and stapes articulate via a ball and socket joint.

 

Options D. Vomer A facial bone forming part of the nasal septum, unrelated to the middle ear.

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. It plays a critical role in hearing by transmitting sound vibrations from the malleus to the stapes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 9

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is due to deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus, also known as spasmodic croup, is characterized by sudden onset of apnea and a loud stridor due to respiratory obstruction caused by laryngospasm. This condition is often associated with rickets, which is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D. Rickets leads to softening and weakening of the bones in children, and it can also cause disturbances in the metabolism of calcium and phosphorus, leading to neuromuscular irritability, which in turn can result in laryngospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects the eyes, leading to conditions such as night blindness and xerophthalmia. It does not cause laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency is rare and typically presents with neurological symptoms due to its role as an antioxidant. It does not cause laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency leads to bleeding disorders because of its role in the synthesis of clotting factors. It is not associated with laryngismus stridulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus, characterized by sudden respiratory obstruction and stridor, is associated with rickets caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Recognizing the link between Vitamin D deficiency and laryngismus stridulus is important for diagnosis and treatment.

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of reactionary hemorrhage post-tonsillectomy and the immediate management is to shift the patient to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the bleeding vessel.

 

Hemorrhage is a common complication of tonsillectomy. It can be primary, reactionary, or secondary:

 

  • Primary hemorrhage occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or blood pressure returning to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels is done under anesthesia if the above measures fail.
  • Secondary hemorrhage is usually seen between the 5th to 10th postoperative day. It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Removal of the clot, topical application of dilute adrenaline or hydrogen peroxide with pressure usually suffice. IV antibiotics are given and the bleeding vessel is electro coagulated or ligated if bleeding continues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate return to the OT for direct intervention is essential in managing post-tonsillectomy bleeding. Ensuring the bleeding vessel is adequately addressed through cauterization or ligation can prevent further complications and promote healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 504, 505

questions.text: A person presents in ENT OPD having nasal blockage with crusts, foul-smelling discharge, and hyposmia. On examination, nose is hard, and biopsy reveals following histopathological findings. What is the likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of nasal blockage, crusts, foul-smelling discharge, and hyposmia, along with the finding of a hard nose and the specific histopathological findings in the biopsy (such as Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies), are indicative of rhinoscleroma caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition that leads to the hardening of the nasal tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinosporidium seeberi: This condition would show sporangia containing endospores on histopathology, which is not seen in this case.

 

 

Option B. Klebsiella ozaenae: Typically causes atrophic rhinitis characterized by foul-smelling discharge and crusting, but it does not cause a hard nose or the specific histopathological findings seen here.

 

 

Option D. Autoimmunity: Autoimmune conditions can cause nasal symptoms but are not characterized by the specific histopathological findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinoscleroma, caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, presents with a hard nose, nasal blockage, crusting, foul-smelling discharge, and specific histopathological findings such as Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl lately having poor scholastic performance. She complains of hearing loss for which she was brought to the clinic by her parents. She breathes with her mouth and has a low tone voice. The X-ray has been performed. On audiometry, 30dB of Bilateral CHL is diagnosed. What could be the best treatment for her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Explanation: 

 

The girl presents with symptoms of adenoid hypertrophy, including mouth breathing, low tone voice, and poor scholastic performance.

 

The lateral view X-ray shows soft tissue opacification in the nasopharynx, indicative of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

The audiometry results show bilateral conductive hearing loss (CHL) at 30dB, likely due to eustachian tube blockage and serous otitis media caused by the enlarged adenoids.

 

The best treatment for this condition is adenoidectomy to remove the hypertrophied adenoids and grommet insertion to drain the middle ear fluid and alleviate the conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy with Myringotomy: While adenoidectomy addresses the root cause, myringotomy without grommet insertion may not adequately resolve the middle ear fluid and could lead to recurrent effusions.

 

Option B. Bone anchored hearing aid: This option is typically used for specific types of hearing loss and is not the first-line treatment for conductive hearing loss caused by adenoid hypertrophy and associated otitis media.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: This addresses the middle ear effusion but does not treat the underlying cause of the adenoid hypertrophy, which would likely result in recurrent issues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of adenoidectomy and grommet insertion effectively addresses both the cause (adenoid hypertrophy) and the symptom (middle ear effusion), providing a comprehensive treatment for bilateral conductive hearing loss in children.

questions.text: 14-year-old boy with recurrent profuse epistaxis and reddish mass in the nasal cavity: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) JNA (Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma)

 

A 14-year-old boy presenting with recurrent, profuse epistaxis (nosebleeds) and a reddish mass in the nasal cavity is highly suggestive of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). JNA is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males. The hallmark symptoms include recurrent severe nosebleeds and nasal obstruction due to the tumor mass.

 

Key characteristics of JNA:

 

  • Occurs in adolescent males
  • Presents with recurrent, profuse epistaxis
  • Appears as a reddish mass in the nasal cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NPC (Nasopharyngeal carcinoma): Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is typically seen in older adults and is associated with risk factors like consumption of nitrosamine-rich foods (e.g., salted fish). It often presents with unilateral hearing loss due to Eustachian tube blockage, leading to serous otitis media. It is not common in adolescents and does not typically present with recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Polyp: Nasal polyps are benign growths in the nasal cavity that usually do not bleed. They can cause nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea but are not typically associated with recurrent, profuse epistaxis.

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Inverted papillomas are benign tumors that usually occur in older adults. They are associated with a risk of malignancy and often present with unilateral nasal obstruction and occasional bleeding but not the recurrent, profuse epistaxis seen in JNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) should be suspected in adolescent males who present with recurrent, profuse epistaxis and a reddish mass in the nasal cavity. This condition is characteristic of this age and gender group and requires specific clinical suspicion for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided as he will have aspirin intolerance.

 

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

 

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

 

Aspirin and COX – 1 inhibitors can exacerbate asthma hence they should be avoided. Rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur.

 

The provocative challenge test with aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is the only diagnostic method.

 

Aspirin desensitization is an important therapeutic option in patients with ST, especially in those patients suffering from recurrent NPs, anosmia, and overdependence on systemic corticosteroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole and Option B. Co-amoxiclav: These are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections, including sinusitis, and do not affect COX-1 activity.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: An antibiotic that is generally used for serious infections where other antibiotics are not suitable. It does not interact with the COX-1 pathway.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

questions.text: A patient presents with a perforation in the tympanic membrane. During the evaluation, a Rinne test is performed. What is the expected outcome of the Rinne test in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negative

 

Perforation of the tympanic membrane results in conductive hearing loss because the sound waves cannot be properly transmitted through the middle ear. In cases of conductive hearing loss, the Rinne test, which compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC), will be negative. This occurs because bone conduction is perceived as louder than air conduction, indicating a conductive defect. The negative Rinne test is characteristic of any lesion or abnormality affecting the external ear, tympanic membrane, or middle ear, as these structures are responsible for sound conduction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive: A positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is louder than bone conduction, which is normal or seen in sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss like that caused by a tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option C. Indeterminate: This is not a standard result for the Rinne test. The Rinne test is typically either positive or negative, and "indeterminate" does not correctly describe the results related to tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option D. Equivocal: An equivocal Rinne test result suggests equal loudness of air and bone conduction, which is not typically associated with tympanic membrane perforation. This term is not commonly used in describing Rinne test outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A perforation in the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss, which is characterized by a negative Rinne test, where bone conduction is heard louder than air conduction.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male was brought to OPD by his mother with reduced hearing since 2 months. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane was observed as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Myringitis Bullosa

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serous otitis media: (glue ear) cases present with hearing loss and mild ear ache. Otoscopy reveals fluid level and air bubbles.

 

 

Option B. Acute otitis media: Patients present with ear ache, fever, ear discharge. Following image shows red and bulging TM.

 

 

Option D. Myringitis Granulosa: Patient usually presents with painless otorrhea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myringitis Bullosa should be considered when a patient presents with the acute onset of ear pain accompanied by visible blisters on the tympanic membrane, particularly in the context of a recent upper respiratory infection or influenza-like illness. Management focuses on pain relief and monitoring for resolution, with antibiotics or antivirals tailored to the underlying cause if identified.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serous Otitis media

 

Child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months with  air fluid levels on otoscopy is suggestive of serous otitis media.

 

Aetiology

 

  1. Eustachian tube block secondary to adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx
  2. Allergy
  3. Unresolved otitis media
  4. Viral infections – adeno and rhinovirus

 

Symptoms

 

The disease affects children of 5–8 years of age. The symptoms include:

 

  1. Conductive hearing loss.
  2. Delayed and defective speech. Because of hearing loss, development of speech is delayed or defective.
  3. Mild earaches.

 

Otoscopic Findings

 

  •  Tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex, and may appear yellow, grey or bluish in color.
  • Thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of malleus or at the periphery of tympanic membrane
  • Tympanic membrane may show varying degree of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
