  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and tympanic membrane transparent
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted

 

Audiometry

 

  •  Pure tone audiometry shows conduction hearing loss
  •  Tympanometry will show B type curve

 

Treatment

 

1. Medical

 

  • Decongestants.
  • Antihistamines or sometimes steroids may be used in cases of allergy.
  • Antibiotics. They are useful in cases of upper respiratory tract infections or unresolved acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Middle Ear Aeration. Patients should repeatedly perform the Valsalva maneuver. Children can be given chewing gum to encourage repeated swallowing which opens the tube.

 

2. Surgical

 

  • Myringotomy and fluid aspiration
  • Grommet insertion
  • Tympanotomy and mastoidectomy
  • Surgical treatment of underlying causes like adenoid hypertrophy, tonsillar hypertrophy etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myringitis bullosa involves the formation of blisters on the tympanic membrane due to inflammation, often associated with viral infections like influenza.

 

  • Symptoms: It is characterized by severe pain, occasionally hearing loss, and a rapid onset following an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • The symptoms of prolonged hearing loss and the otoscopic findings of fluid levels visible in the image are not typical for myringitis bullosa, which usually presents with acute, painful blistering rather than effusion.

Option C. Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, typically of rapid onset, involving signs of acute infection such as ear pain, fever, and general malaise.

 

  • Symptoms: The tympanic membrane often appears red and bulging due to the presence of pus and fluid, and the condition is usually accompanied by significant pain and fever.
  • Why Not: The child's symptoms described do not include acute infectious signs like significant pain or fever, and the duration of hearing loss suggests a more chronic condition.

Option D. Pneumo Tympanum refers to the presence of air in the middle ear space, which is not typically associated with fluid. It can occur due to trauma, barotrauma, or as a rare complication of severe nasal congestion.

 

  • Symptoms: This condition might present with a feeling of fullness or popping in the ear but not with the fluid level and air bubbles typically seen in fluid accumulation conditions.
  • Why Not: The presence of air bubbles alongside fluid specifically points towards fluid accumulation rather than just air, making pneumo tympanum less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serous otitis media requires comprehensive management to prevent long-term effects on hearing and speech development. Early intervention, both medical and surgical, is essential for restoring normal ear function and preventing recurrent episodes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 84

questions.text: Septal perforation caused due to surgery of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SMR (Submucous Resection)

  

Septal perforation is more commonly associated with SMR (Submucous Resection) than with septoplasty. In SMR, the deviated part of the septum, which includes both the bony and cartilaginous components, is removed. This removal can lead to the loss of structural support from the cartilage or bone. If there is any tear in the mucosal flaps that cover the septum, it may fail to heal properly due to the absence of underlying support, leading to a septal perforation.

 

During SMR, the absence of this central support structure means that even a minor mucosal tear can result in a perforation because the mucosal flaps on either side of the septum may fuse incorrectly, creating a hole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): FESS is a procedure focused on the sinuses and not the septum itself, thus it does not typically result in septal perforation. This surgery involves the removal of sinus tissue and does not interfere with the septal structure.

 

Option C. Septoplasty: In septoplasty, the septum is straightened by removing or reshaping the cartilage and bone but importantly, the removed parts are replaced back between the mucosal flaps. This restoration of structure reduces the likelihood of perforations because the mucosal layers are supported by the replaced bone or cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septal perforation is a recognized complication of SMR due to the complete removal of septal cartilage and bone without replacement, which can lead to mucosal tears and eventual perforation if the layers do not heal correctly.

questions.text: Audiogram of a patient is given. Find the sign that can be seen in the same case. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwartz sign

 

The audiogram shows a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz, known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis. Otosclerosis is a condition where abnormal bone growth occurs in the middle ear, particularly affecting the stapes bone, leading to conductive hearing loss.

 

Schwartz sign is associated with otosclerosis and refers to a reddish hue seen behind the intact tympanic membrane near the oval window due to increased vascularity from active otosclerotic processes. It is a contraindication for stapes surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balance sign: This sign is unrelated to otosclerosis. Balance sign generally refers to signs related to balance issues and is not associated with hearing loss patterns on an audiogram.

 

Option B. Hennebert sign: Hennebert sign is a false positive fistula test that does not relate to otosclerosis. It is more commonly associated with conditions like Ménière's disease or syphilis affecting the inner ear.

 

Option D. Hitzelberger sign: This sign is seen in acoustic neuroma and involves hypesthesia of the posterior wall of the external auditory canal. It is not connected with otosclerosis or the Carhart's notch observed in the audiogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz on an audiogram is a specific finding in otosclerosis, and Schwartz sign, a reddish hue behind the tympanic membrane, is an associated clinical sign indicating active otosclerotic processes.

questions.text: What is the definitive approach for managing uncontrollable vertigo caused by Meniere's disease?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Labyrinthectomy

 

Definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniere’s disease is labyrinthectomy.

 

The step-up management of Meniere’s disease is

 

  1. Dietary changes – low salt and caffeine free diet
  2. First-line medical treatment to prevent recurrence of vertigo may include betahistine dihydrochloride 16 mg thrice daily and/or diuretics. Betahistine has a limited side effect profile while diuretics can cause electrolyte disturbances, potentially interacting with patient-specific drugs and conditions.
  3. Salvage treatment in case of medical treatment failure may include repetitive intratympanic injections of dexamethasone.
  4. In refractory cases after intratympanic injection of dexamethasone, intratympanic injection of gentamicin (as-needed) can be offered (recommendation grade A). This treatment is based on the vestibulotoxic effect of gentamicin and aims to destroy vestibular hair cell function (therefore also called partial chemo labyrinthectomy).
  5. Surgical destruction (Labyrinthectomy, Vestibular nerve section): Labyrinthectomy totally destroys cochlear and vestibular function and are thus used only when cochlear function is not serviceable and when conservative treatments fail. It has shown the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), and is considered as the single definitive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetazolamide: This medication is not typically used as a definitive treatment for Meniere's disease. It may be used in some cases for its diuretic effect to manage symptoms, but it does not address the root causes or provide long-term control of vertigo.

 

Option C. Vestibular neurectomy: This surgical procedure involves severing the vestibular nerve to alleviate vertigo while preserving hearing. It is considered for patients where hearing preservation is a priority, but it is not as definitive as labyrinthectomy for completely eliminating vertigo.

 

Option D. Intratympanic gentamicin: This treatment involves injecting gentamicin, a vestibulotoxic antibiotic, into the middle ear to chemically ablate vestibular function. It is used as a salvage treatment for vertigo control in Meniere's disease when other medical treatments fail. However, it is not considered as definitive as labyrinthectomy due to its potential for hearing loss and the need for repeated treatments in some cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with Meniere's disease who have debilitating vertigo and no serviceable hearing in the affected ear, labyrinthectomy offers a definitive solution with a very high success rate in eliminating vertigo. This surgical option is reserved for severe cases where other less invasive treatments have been exhausted.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presented in ENT OPD with hoarseness of voice following a quarrel in public. On laryngoscopy, the following picture is seen. Management of this patient is? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MLS removal

 

Explanation:

 

The laryngoscopic image shows a unilateral large mass at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, which is consistent with a vocal polyp. Vocal polyps typically result from vocal abuse or trauma and can cause hoarseness of voice. The definitive management of a vocal polyp is Microsuspension Laryngoscopy (MLS) removal, which involves surgically excising the polyp to restore normal voice function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not indicated for benign lesions such as vocal polyps. It is used primarily for malignant conditions.

 

Option C. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is not a standard treatment for vocal polyps. It is more commonly used for other types of lesions.

 

Option D. Voice rest & Speech therapy: Voice rest and speech therapy are generally recommended for vocal nodules, which are smaller and often bilateral. While these therapies can help in reducing strain on the vocal cords, they are not the primary treatment for vocal polyps, which require surgical removal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The management of a vocal polyp, which presents as a unilateral mass on the vocal cord, is surgical removal via Microsuspension Laryngoscopy (MLS). Voice rest and speech therapy are more suitable for smaller, bilateral vocal nodules.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presented in OPD as shown below. She is a known case of Diabetes Mellitus. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucormycosis

 

Fungal Infection that can happen in uncontrolled DM – Mucormycosis, Aspergillosis.

 

Mucormycosis:

 

  • Caused by mucor, rhizopus.
  • Invades very rapidly to the surrounding tissue → into orbit → cranium
  • Black eschars are formed
  • Can be life-threatening if not attended immediately with surgical debridement, FESS and antifungal medication (Amphotericin-B).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillosis: This fungal infection can cause sinusitis but usually doesn't present with the rapid, aggressive invasion characteristic of mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Foreign Body and Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: These are less likely given the typical presentation and risk factors, and they don't typically present with the aggressive necrotic features seen in mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In diabetic patients presenting with black necrotic tissue and signs of invasive fungal infection in the nasal or orbital area, mucormycosis is the most likely diagnosis, requiring immediate and aggressive treatment to prevent potentially life-threatening complications.

choices.text: Conservative management with observation and ice chips.
Immediate cauterization of the bleeding site

questions.text: A 10 year old girl post tonsillectomy ate a packet of chips 2-3 days after the surgery and now came to the hospital with oral bleed. What shall be the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antibiotics with semisolid food

 

Antibiotics with semisolid food is one approach to manage postoperative bleeding after tonsillectomy. The rationale behind antibiotics is to prevent or treat any possible infection that might have been caused by the chips. Semisolid food is recommended to minimize the mechanical irritation to the tonsillar fossa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical exploration may be required if the bleeding is significant or if it does not stop with conservative measures. This would involve returning to the operating room to identify the source of bleeding and achieve hemostasis.

 

Option C. Conservative management with observation and ice chips can be appropriate for minor bleeding. Ice chips can help with vasoconstriction and pain relief. Observation is crucial to ensure that bleeding does not worsen.

 

Option D. Immediate cauterization of the bleeding site may be necessary if the bleeding is active and significant. This would typically be done under controlled conditions, possibly in the operating room.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-tonsillectomy bleeding is a potential complication that can be managed conservatively with antibiotics and dietary modifications, such as semisolid food, to prevent further mechanical trauma to the surgical site. However, the approach to management should be tailored to the severity of the bleeding and the clinical condition of the patient, with more aggressive interventions like surgical exploration or cauterization reserved for significant or persistent bleeding.

questions.text: Sludder’s neuralgia is due to compression of anterior ethmoidal nerve by septal spur in the region of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle turbinate

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, also known as anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, occurs due to the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve. This nerve provides sensory innervation to parts of the nasal cavity and the anterior part of the cranial cavity. A septal spur, which is a sharp bony projection from the nasal septum, can impinge on the middle turbinate where the anterior ethmoidal nerve traverses. This compression can cause pain and headache in the regions supplied by the nerve, commonly leading to facial pain and nasal discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior turbinate: While the superior turbinate is located higher in the nasal cavity, it is not typically involved in the compression causing Sludder’s neuralgia. The anterior ethmoidal nerve runs closer to the middle turbinate.

 

Option B. Inferior turbinate: The inferior turbinate is situated lower in the nasal cavity and does not typically come into contact with the septal spur affecting the anterior ethmoidal nerve. Therefore, it is not involved in Sludder’s neuralgia.

 

Option D. Supreme turbinate: The supreme turbinate is an anatomical variant that some individuals have above the superior turbinate. This is not commonly implicated in conditions involving the anterior ethmoidal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sludder’s neuralgia, or anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, is caused by the compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve by a septal spur in the region of the middle turbinate. This condition results in facial pain and headache due to nerve irritation.

choices.text: Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to right ear
Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear

questions.text:
A woman presents with impaired hearing. Her audiometry findings are given below:  (INICET Nov 2021)

 

 

Pick the right combination of tuning fork test results that would be seen in this patient. (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

Based on the provided tympanogram findings, it is likely that the tuning fork tests for this patient would reveal a positive left Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the right ear (normal ear).

 

 

INTERPRETATION OF AUDIOGRAM

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap (AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.
  • In the question given above, left sided air conduction and bone conduction curves do not have any gap and they are occupying middle part of the graph. Hence, it is left SNHL.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to right ear: This result would be expected in conductive hearing loss, not SNHL.

 

Option B. Left Rinne's test negative, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This also indicates conductive hearing loss, which is not supported by the audiogram findings.

 

Option D. Left Rinne's test positive, Weber's test lateralized to left ear: This would indicate normal hearing or mild hearing loss in the right ear, which does not match the audiogram showing significant SNHL in the left ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne's test remains positive, and Weber's test lateralizes to the better-hearing ear. The provided audiogram indicates left-sided SNHL, resulting in a positive Rinne test on the left and Weber lateralizing to the right ear.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 24, 25

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with a history of nasal obstruction for the last 2 months. A CT scan was done, and the following findings are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antrochoanal polyp

 

The CT scan shows a mass originating from the maxillary sinus extending into the choana and nasopharynx, indicative of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps are benign lesions that arise from the maxillary sinus, extend through the sinus ostium, and grow into the nasopharynx. This causes nasal obstruction, which aligns with the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid hypertrophy: Adenoid hypertrophy occurs in the nasopharynx and is characterized by enlarged adenoids, leading to nasal obstruction and mouth breathing. It does not typically present with a mass extending from the maxillary sinus.

 

Option B. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: This is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs predominantly in adolescent males. It arises from the nasopharynx and extends into adjacent areas, not from the maxillary sinus.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This malignant tumor arises from the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx. It usually presents with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The mass in the CT scan originating from the maxillary sinus is not consistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

An antrochoanal polyp originates from the maxillary sinus and extends through the choana into the nasopharynx, causing nasal obstruction. The presence of a gap between the tumor and the posterior pharyngeal wall on imaging, known as the "dot sign," supports this diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following middle ear structure is a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot plate of stapes

 

The malleus, incus, and stapes are the three ossicles of the middle ear that transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear. 

 

The footplate of the stapes is the portion of the stapes that sits in the oval window of the cochlea. It is unique among the ossicles because its development involves contributions from neural crest cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malleus: Develops from the first branchial (pharyngeal) arch, also known as Meckel's cartilage, which is not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option B. Stapes: While it is part of the same series of ossicles as the malleus, the main structure of the stapes develops from the second branchial (pharyngeal) arch, known as Reichert's cartilage, which is also not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option D. Incus: Like the malleus, is derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It too is not a derivative of neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The footplate of the stapes in the middle ear is the structure derived from neural crest cells, distinguishing it from the other ossicles (malleus and incus), which are derived from the first and second pharyngeal arches and not from neural crest cells.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

The correct match for Wullstein’s classification is a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

  1. Type II – 2. graft placed over the incus
  2. Type III – 4. columella tympanoplasty
  3. Type IV – 3. Cavum minor
  4. Type V – 1. Fenestration tympanoplasty

 

  1. Type II (Ossiculoplasty): Malleus partially eroded; ossicular chain reconstruction involves placing a graft over the incus.
  2. Type III (Columella Effect): Malleus and incus eroded; new TM coupled to the stapes head, referred to as columella tympanoplasty.
  3. Type IV (Cavum Minor): Stapedial head also eroded; new TM and new ossicular coupling to the stapes footplate.
  4. Type V (Fenestration Operation): Creating a fenestra and coupling the ossicular chain to the scala vestibuli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty provides a systematic approach to different types of middle ear reconstructions based on the extent of ossicular damage and required surgical repair.

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior canal wall
Focal bone erosion with intact meatal width

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about external auditory canal cholesteatoma (EACC)? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior canal wall

 

Explanation:

 

External auditory canal cholesteatoma (EACC) differs from keratosis obturans in several key aspects:

 

  • EACC is characterized by focal erosion of the canal wall, typically affecting the inferior or posterior walls. Unlike keratosis obturans, it does not cause circumferential widening of the meatus.
  • The pathophysiology involves localized failure of epithelial migration along the posterior canal wall, leading to accumulation and invasion of squamous epithelium into the bone.
  • Unlike keratosis obturans, EACC is not typically associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis or sinusitis.
  • The keratin debris in EACC appears as dark or brown-colored masses, unlike the pearly white layered appearance seen in keratosis obturans.

 

Other Option:

 

Option B. Focal bone erosion with intact meatal width: Incorrect. because EACC causes focal bone erosion without widespread meatal widening, unlike keratosis obturans.

 

Option C. Associated bronchiectasis and sinusitis: Incorrect. as systemic associations like bronchiectasis and sinusitis are characteristic of keratosis obturans, not EACC.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect. as only option A is true for EACC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the distinguishing features between external auditory canal cholesteatoma and keratosis obturans is crucial for proper diagnosis and management. While both conditions involve keratin accumulation, they differ in their presentation, associated findings, and clinical course.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

 

Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation but in dysphagia to prevent aspiration of food.

 

The Super-Supraglottic Swallow technique is employed for patients experiencing diminished airway closure. To perform this technique, patients are directed to take a deep breath and tightly hold it while bearing down. They should maintain this breath hold and bear down as they swallow. Immediately after the swallow (before inhaling), they are instructed to cough, followed by a forceful swallow once more (before inhaling). This sequence is aimed at enhancing airway protection during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) is a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. Occlusion of the stoma shunts the exhaled air through the TEP into the esophagus producing vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter resulting in phonation.

Option B. Esophageal speech is phonation produced by vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter.

 

Option C. Polite yawning also called nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is indicated for olfaction rehabilitation post laryngectomy. This maneuver induces a negative pressure in the oral cavity and oropharynx, which generates a nasal airflow, enabling odorous substances to reach the olfactory epithelium again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Super supraglottic swallow technique is crucial for enhancing airway protection in dysphagia management but is not utilized in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation, where the focus is primarily on restoring voice and smell functions through other specialized techniques.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition 352, 353; Scott Brown 7th edition, Volume 2, Page No. 2090
